intro: Lytanthus salicinus, commonly known as the willow-leaf lytanthus, is a flowering plant native to the temperate regions of the southern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and prefers partial to full sunlight. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a soft, velvety texture, while its flowers range in color from white to pink. Lytanthus salicinus is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and natural landscapes.
